Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, swirling my spoon in my cereal, half-listening as my stepdad and stepsister tossed around ideas for the weekend. “Let’s all go hiking on Saturday!” my stepsister suggested, her eyes bright. My stepdad nodded, looking at me expectantly. I knew how much it meant to them that I joined in, that I made an effort to be part of this new family. I wanted to say yes, to be included, to not be the odd one out.

But my phone buzzed with a message from the synagogue group chat: “We need one more for the minyan at the funeral service Saturday morning. Can anyone help?” I stared at the screen, my heart pounding. I knew how important it was to be there, to help someone say Kaddish for a loved one. It was a mitzvah, a responsibility I took seriously.

I looked up at my family, their faces full of hope, and then back at my phone. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, pulling me in opposite directions. I felt my throat tighten as I tried to figure out what to say, caught between two worlds that both needed me.
